newsitem.title: MEXICO: ICA eyes rail, port privatization.
newsitem.headline: ICA eyes rail, port privatization.

text.p: Mexican construction company ICA is hoping to have its finger in several pies about to be privatized, a company executive said in an interview.
ICA is interested in key rail routes that will be open to private operators as part of a forthcoming rail privatization program, especially the busy Mexico City-Ciudad Juarez route.

"We will be looking to snap up the main routes...the one that goes from the capital to the U.S. border (Mexico City-Ciudad Juarez), which comes real close to here and the one that goes to Nuevo Laredo, too," said Jose Puron, director of Projects and telecommunications at ICA.
ICA will also soon begin building an electricity co-generation plant in the Gulf of Mexico port of Altamira, which will be run by the holding company Alfa.
Puron did not mention any figures, but expected the plant to start up in 1998.
As a construction company, ICA was also interested in ports scheduled to be privatized, he said.

Furthermore, ICA, in alliance with Fluor Daniel, was involved in laying a fibre-optic network for telephone company Avantel, due to enter the long-distance telephone market when it is thrown open to competition in 1997.
